column1: '''Middle English 'Losenger': Sketch of an etymological and semantic enquiry''' is the title of a paper delivered by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] at the Congrès Internationale de Philologie Moderne, held at the University of Liège from [[10 September

The paper is an investigation of the [[Middle English]] word (of French origin) 'losenger'.<ref group="note">''Losenger'': A flatterer; a deceiver; a cozener. (Source: ''Webster's Revised Unabridged Dictionary''. 1913, C. & G. Merriam Co.)</ref> Tolkien traces the etymology of the word in [[Wikipedia:Geoffrey Chaucer
column2: Geoffrey Chaucer]]'s ''Legend of Good Women'' and in various [[wikipedia:Proto-Germanic language

column1: In [[1953]], the essay was published in ''[[Essais de philologie moderne (1951)]]'', the collection of the conference proceedings, and in an offprint ([[Middle English 'Losenger' (publication)
column2: ''Middle English 'Losenger': Sketch of an etymological and semantic enquiry'']]).<ref>''An Illustrated Tolkien Bibliography'', at Tolkienbooks.net</ref>
